user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1ProcessMessageBlock:
```c
static void
SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (struct SHA1Context *context)
{
  const uint32_t K[] = { 0x5A827999, 0x6ED9EBA1, 0x8F1BBCDC, 0xCA62C1D6 };
  int i;
  uint32_t temp;
  uint32_t W[80];
  uint32_t A, B, C, D, E;

  for (i = 0; i < 16; i++)
  {
    W[i] = ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4]) << 24;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 1]) << 16;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 2]) << 8;
    W[i] |= context->message_block[i * 4 + 3];
  }
  for (i = 16; i < 80; i++)
  {
    W[i]
      = SHA1CircularShift (1, W[i - 3] ^ W[i - 8] ^ W[i - 14] ^ W[i - 16]);
  }
  A = context->intermediate_hash[0];
  B = context->intermediate_hash[1];
  C = context->intermediate_hash[2];
  D = context->intermediate_hash[3];
  E = context->intermediate_hash[4];
  for (i = 0; i < 20; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | ((~B) & D)) + E + W[i]
           + K[0];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 20; i < 40; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[1];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 40; i < 60; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | (B & D) | (C & D)) + E
           + W[i] + K[2];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 60; i < 80; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[3];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  context->intermediate_hash[0] += A;
  context->intermediate_hash[1] += B;
  context->intermediate_hash[2] += C;
  context->intermediate_hash[3] += D;
  context->intermediate_hash[4] += E;
  context->message_block_index = 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no syntactically unreachable code in the submitted function. Reasoning by inspection:
- There are no return, goto, longjmp, abort, or similar transfer statements that would make any subsequent statements unreachable.
- There are no conditional constructs (if/else with constant-false condition, #if 0, or switch with unreachable case labels) that would render code unreachable.
- The four sequential for-loops (i = 0..15, i = 16..79, i = 0..19, i = 20..39, i = 40..59, i = 60..79) are all standard bounded loops with well-defined ranges; none is infinite, and each loop body is reachable when the loop executes.
- Declarations and assignments (K[], W[], A..E, temp) are all used later in the function; there are no dead assignments followed by an unconditional return that would make subsequent code unreachable.
- The final updates to context->intermediate_hash[] and message_block_index = 0 are reachable at the end of the function.

Note: I did not flag any fragments because there is no clear unreachable code within this function as presented. If external definitions (for example, SHA1CircularShift implemented via a macro that expands to an unconditional jump/return, or conditional compilation around parts of the function) exist elsewhere, those could introduce unreachable code; such cases require inspecting those external definitions or build configuration.
